results:
Based on the search results, here are the key publication facts about Jane Austen's *Emma* from 1815:

## Publication Details

*Emma* was first published on December 23, 1815, though the title page bore the date 1816. The novel was published in three volumes and had a first edition print run of 2,000 copies—Jane Austen's largest first edition print run to date.

## Publisher and Business Arrangement

The novel was submitted to London publisher John Murray II in autumn 1815. Murray initially offered Austen £450 for *Emma* plus the copyrights of *Mansfield Park* and *Sense and Sensibility*, which she refused. Instead, Austen negotiated with Murray to publish *Emma* on a commission basis, where she paid for printing and advertising the books, and Murray received a commission for distributing and selling them.

## Prince Regent Dedication

Unlike Jane Austen's other works, *Emma* included a dedication to the Prince of Wales (Prince Regent). While visiting her brother Henry in London in fall 1815, Austen's identity became known to the Prince and his librarian, James Stanier-Clarke, and she was invited to tour Carlton House. Stanier-Clarke wrote that she "was at liberty to dedicate any future work" to the Regent—a subtle royal request that she decided could not be ignored. The dedication read: "To His Royal Highness, The Prince Regent. This work is, by his Royal Highness's permission, most respectfully dedicated by His Royal Highness's dutiful and obedient humble servant, The Author".

## Contemporary Reviews

Early reviews of *Emma* were generally favourable, and were more numerous than those of any other of Austen's novels. One important review was written by Sir Walter Scott and appeared anonymously in March 1816 in the *Quarterly Review*, although it was requested by John Murray prior to publication. Prior to publishing, John Murray's reader, William Gifford, who was also the editor of the *Quarterly Review*, said of the novel "Of Emma I have nothing but good to say".

## Sales Performance

John Murray's ledgers show that by October 1816 only 1,248 copies of *Emma* had been sold—slightly less than two-thirds of the initial print run. By February 1817, only around 1,500 copies had sold and Jane had earned only £38.18 in profit, after losses were deducted from the second edition of *Mansfield Park*.
